bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 162, Number 24 (Wednesday, February 10, 2016)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. EMMER of Minnesota:H.R. 4518.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Clause 1, Section 8 of Article 1 of the United StatesConstitution which reads: ``The Congress shall have Power tolay and collect Taxes, Duties, Imposts, and Excises, to paythe Debts, and provide for the common Defense and GeneralWelfare of the United States; but all Duties and Imposts andExcises shall be uniform throughout the United States.''[Page H710]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

summary.text:
Corporate Rate Equality and Trade Empowerment Jobs Act of 2016 or the Create Jobs Act

This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to lower the rate of tax on the taxable income of corporations to the greater of: (1) 10%, or (2) the rate that is 5% below the average corporate income tax rate for Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development countries other than the United States. The bill also sets forth a procedure for a congressional joint resolution approving an increase in the corporate tax rate.

bill.title: Create Jobs Act

item.title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to lower the corporate rate of income tax to the OECD average, and for other purposes.
Corporate Rate Equality and Trade Empowerment Jobs Act of 2016

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
